x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement: Tropical megacities face skyrocketing ambient temperatures, heavy AC use, and urban heat islands that increase energy demand and health risks. Low-income households pay disproportionately for cooling/diesel backup yet rarely benefit from city-scale mitigation programs. The challenge: no simple mechanism to incentivize wide adoption of reflective/cooling roof upgrades, measure impact, and funnel finance to low-income households.

How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

marketplace that connects materials suppliers, micro-installers, NGOs, and household owners. The platform: (a) registers retrofit projects, (b) measures baseline & post-installation temperature/energy via low-cost sensors or citizen reporting, (c) issues tradable CoolCredits (for local green funds, donors, or municipal rebates), and (d) manages installers, warranties and claims.
ServiceNow uses:

  • Asset Management for installed roof assets and warranties;
  • Field Service Management to schedule installer teams and quality checks;
  • Flow Designer to automate validation, credit issuance and payments;
  • IntegrationHub to ingest satellite/surface temperature APIs and IoT sensor feeds;
  • Performance Analytics for neighborhood heat maps and impact dashboards.

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

  • Low-cost temperature sensors & IoT connectivity (LoRaWAN or intermittent GSM uploads);
  • Satellite/open-data surface temp APIs for baseline validation;
  • Mobile money/payment rails;
  • Local supply chain for reflective materials and trained micro-installers.

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

Accurate impact measurement at household scale (noise from other variables), verifying installations, preventing double-counting of credits, upfront financing for low-income households, and municipal policy alignment. Mitigation: conservative verification protocols, community-level sampling, and partnership with local NGOs/wards
